        [image002.jpg]
                            [**2169-11-22**]  02:51 AM
                            [**2169-11-22**]  04:57 AM
   TCO2
   18
   20
   Other labs: Lactic Acid:2.4 mmol/L
   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure:
   Likely tachypnea secondary to metabolic acidosis; pt was tiring out
   trying to compensate by respiratory means
   Has been having recently worsening dyspnea on exertion, stable
   orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation in the ED. Repeat
   CXR shows increased bilateral opacities suggesting pulmonary edema.
   Heart failure is possible with her BNP elevation and history of
   orthopnea, although she has no known heart failure. Influenza another
   possibility, though less likely, given concurrent fever and dry cough.
   CXR was not concerning for pneumonia or fluid overload.  Consider also
   ischemia given report of chest pain, although EKG reportedly negative
   and cardiac markers negative x2, so not likely ACS. ABG shows good
   oxygenation and patient has been switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.
   PE less likely
   - Cont PSV for now and wean as tolerated
   - R/o influenza
   - f/u w TTE from this morning
   .
   # Septic shock:
   Bandemia and lactate improving, still febrile and requiring pressors.
   Sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD dilation with
   sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known choledocholithiasis. No
   other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with vancomycin and pip-tazo
   - ERCP today for biliary drainage
   - Trend CBC/diff, lactate, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   - Check ScvO2
   .
    # Anion gap acidosis:
   Most likely lactic acidosis secondary to sepsis.  Also has a non-gap
   acidosis, likely from chronic diarrhea.  Gap acidosis improving with
   IVF.
   - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol
   - trend lactate
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - f/u Urine lytes
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia
   Likely secondary to sepsis.
   - send DIC labs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2169-11-22**] 03:45 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2169-11-22**] 03:45 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  pneumoboots, subq heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:  bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:  Husband
   [**Name (NI) 156**] status: Full (Presumed)
 need to confirm w husband
   Disposition:
   ------ Protected Section ------
   MICU ATTENDING PROGRESS NOTE
   I saw and examined the patient and was physically present with the ICU
   team for the key portions of the services provided. I agree with the
   resident note, including the assessment and plan. I would emphasize and
   add the following points: 85F a w/ renal ca, dementia,
   choledocolithiasis presents with n/v X 2 days, diarrhea, dyspnea, Fever
   100.9.  In ED CXR clear initially but intubated for ? evolving
   infiltrates and resp distress. RIJ CVL placed for hypotension with IVF
   given, levophed then started. Received vanco/zosyn  Labs concerning for
   biliary sepsis with t bili 9.9, transaminitis, AGMA, lactate 4.5, 18%
   bandemia and cr 2.6.  RUQ with dil cbd, sludge with ERCP consulted and
   plan for ERCP in am today.
   PE: BP: 90/50  HR90  RR 19  T: 100.8  98% ACV--> PS 12/5 40% Intubated,
   sedated, jaundiced, perrla, CTA, RR, soft + BS, non T at ruq, no edema
   LABS: wbc 25 (4.8), 19-->0 bands, hct 31.6, plt 93 (140), na 137, cr
   2.4 (2.6), lactate 2.4 (4.5), t bili 6.4 (9.9), ast/alt decreasing, inr
   1.3, 7.31/37/133, trop 0.02, BNP 5600, u/a neg
   ECG with NSR TWI 3, v1. no ST changes
   Imaging reviewed: cxr appears rotated, pulm vascular fullness, no focal
   infiltrate though would watch r mid zone for possible evolving asp pna
   A/P: Sepsis appears from biliary source/cholangitis, c/b arf and resp
   failure.  Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary lung process, as CXR
   is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of met acidosis she
   fatigued. There is a component of mild demand ischemia by trop without
   frank ecg changes.  Agree with plan to manage biliary sepsis with broad
   antibx (vanco, zosyn for now f/u cx data), plan for ercp today to
   relieve obstruction.  She does not appear fully tanked from volume
   standpoint.  Will continue aggressive IVF (LR given NG as well as AGMA)
   for cvp > 10, weaning pressor off, following u/o, trending lactate,
   lfts, a/l.  Will continue current vent support as she is oxygenating
   well and appears comfortable on PS. Follow abgs closely for signs of
   fatigue noting her continued met acidosis. Evidence of mild demand
   ischemia in setting of septic picture--trop are  flat and without
   progressive ecg changes.  Volume may be an issue in setting of
   extubation.  TTE will be helpful. . Her ARF likely [**3-13**] vol repletion
   from sepsis, n/v and diarrhea.  Aggressive fluids as above, send urine
   lytes. Thrombocytopenia likely in part dilutional and related to
   sepsis, also concerning for DIC. Send dic panel. Low suspicion for
   HIT.  ICU prophy. Consider a-line placement if unable to wean off
   pressor. Remainder of plan as outlined in resident note. Need to
   confirm code status w/ family.
   Patient is critically ill
   Total time: 55 min.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 143**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 144**], MD
   on:[**2169-11-22**] 02:11 PM ------

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock. She was intubated in the emergency department due to respiratory distress and was found to have bilateral opacities on chest X-ray suggestive of pulmonary edema. Her blood cultures are pending, but she has already shown improvement in her bandemia and lactate levels.

The patient's respiratory status is being managed with pressure support ventilation (PSV) at a rate of 12 cmH2O and FiO2 of 40%. Her oxygenation is good, and she is tolerating the ventilator well.

The patient's septic shock is being managed with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, and is planned to undergo ERCP today for biliary drainage. Her anion gap acidosis is likely due to lactic acidosis secondary to sepsis, and her non-gap acidosis is likely due to chronic diarrhea.

The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Her thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis, and she has a low suspicion for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Continued septic shock and organ dysfunction
2. Respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
3. Acute kidney injury and need for dialysis
4. Thrombocytopenia and risk of bleeding
5. Anion gap acidosis and potential for further decompensation
6. Chronic diarrhea and potential for electrolyte imbalance
7. Biliary sepsis and potential for further complications

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

1. Continued management of septic shock with broad-spectrum antibiotics and fluid resuscitation
2. Aggressive fluid management to maintain CVP > 10 mmHg
3. Weaning of pressors off as tolerated
4. Trending of lactate, LFTs, and ABGs
5. ERCP today for biliary drainage
6. Follow-up blood cultures, urine cultures, and imaging studies
7. Consideration of a-line placement if unable to wean off pressors
8. Low suspicion for HIT, but will send DIC panel
9. Thrombocytopenia likely related to sepsis, but will also consider DIC
10. Need to confirm code status with family.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia, who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock. She was intubated in the emergency department due to acute respiratory failure. She is currently on pressure support ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40% and is being treated for septic shock with broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors. She has an anion gap acidosis and acute kidney injury, which is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk of developing further respiratory failure due to her underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the potential for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing further sepsis due to her ongoing infection and the potential for bacterial translocation from the gut.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed appropriately.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications if not managed with platelet transfusions.
5. Anion Gap Acidosis: The patient's anion gap acidosis may worsen if not managed with appropriate treatment of the underlying cause.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of hypertension and renal cancer may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of choledocholithiasis and chronic diarrhea may increase her risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis or bowel obstruction.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia, who presented with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and vasopressors. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.2°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/51 mmHg. Her respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%. However, she has a significant anion gap acidosis and is at risk for acute kidney injury and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of smoking and recent chest pain, pneumonia is a possible complication. Further evaluation, including a repeat CXR and sputum culture, is necessary to rule out this diagnosis.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of hypertension, renal cancer, and orthopnea suggests that she may be at risk for cardiac complications, including heart failure and ischemia. Further evaluation, including a TTE and cardiac markers, is necessary to rule out these diagnoses.
3. Biliary Complications: The patient's choledocholithiasis and CBD dilation with sludge suggest that she may be at risk for further biliary complications, including pancreatitis and cholangitis. ERCP today for biliary drainage is necessary to prevent these complications.
4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's baseline creatinine of 1.2-1.4 and recent IVF suggest that she may be at risk for AKI. Close monitoring of her renal function and avoidance of nephrotoxins are necessary to prevent this complication.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's recent thrombocytopenia may be secondary to sepsis, and further evaluation, including DIC labs, is necessary to rule out this diagnosis.
6. VAP: The patient's intubation and mechanical ventilation make her at risk for VAP. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and prompt treatment of any respiratory infections are necessary to prevent this complication.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a multi-lumen central venous catheter (CVC) inserted at 03:45 AM on [**2169-11-22**]. The patient has been receiving various medications, including norepinephrine, midazolam, and fentanyl, to manage their hemodynamic and respiratory status.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 94/51 mmHg. They are receiving oxygen therapy via an endotracheal tube and are on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 17 cmH2O. The patient's respiratory rate is 19 breaths per minute, and their oxygen saturation is 100%.

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a total input of 369 mL and output of 150 mL, resulting in a balance of 219 mL. Their hemodynamic monitoring includes central venous pressure (CVP) of 6 mmHg and cardiac output (CO) of 9.3 L/min.

The patient's laboratory results show a lactic acid level of 2.4 mmol/L, which may indicate a degree of metabolic acidosis. Their blood gases indicate a pH of 7.31, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 37 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 133 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their critical condition, with no assessment of peripheral pulses, skin, or neurologic function.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: Given the patient's elevated lactic acid level and possible metabolic acidosis, there is a risk of sepsis or septic shock.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate and PIP suggest a possible respiratory failure or worsening of their underlying lung disease.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hemodynamic monitoring suggests a possible cardiovascular instability, which may be related to their underlying condition or the medications they are receiving.
4. Catheter-related complications: The patient's multi-lumen CVC may be at risk for complications such as infection, thrombosis, or catheter-related bloodstream infections.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be effective, and there is a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's risk of VTE is high due to their immobility and underlying condition.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory support and possible aspiration of oral secretions may increase their risk of developing pneumonia.
8. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's underlying condition and possible sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or hepatic dysfunction.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.

   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of
   met acidosis she fatigued. Has been having recently worsening dyspnea
   on exertion, stable orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation
   in the ED. Heart failure is less likely as echo and CXR do not show any
   evidence of this. ABG shows good oxygenation and patient has been
   switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.
   - Cont PSV for now and wean as tolerated; consider sbt once patient can
   tolerate no sedation and no pressors
   - goal to extubate patient today
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP yesterday showed significant pus and s/p stent
   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with vancomycin and pip-tazo until
   sensitivies return
   - Trend CBC/diff, lactate, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   - Check ScvO2
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. DIC labs equivical; low
   suscipicion of HIT as timing does not correlate.
   - Concerning as platelets continuing to decrease. Vancomycin/Zosyn may
   be a possibility as known to cause thrombocytopenia.
   - Repeat DIC labs
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol; will give bicarb as needed for bicarb
   less than 18 or LR if needs resuscitation to prevent further  NG

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia, who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. The patient has undergone ERCP and stent placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is intubated and on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 40%. The ABG shows good oxygenation, and the patient is being weaned off sedation and pressors.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a mildly dilated left atrium and normal left ventricular function. The estimated cardiac index is normal. The patient has trace aortic regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation.
* Renal status: The patient has acute kidney injury likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. The creatinine is stable at 2.1, and the patient is receiving IVFs to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg.
* Hematological status: The patient has thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis. The platelet count is decreasing, and the patient is at risk of bleeding.
* Metabolic status: The patient has a mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis. The gap has closed, and the lactate has normalized.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk of respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of sepsis due to her underlying infection and compromised immune system.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient is at risk of acute kidney injury due to her underlying renal disease and sepsis.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient is at risk of bleeding due to her thrombocytopenia.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient is at risk of developing metabolic acidosis due to her underlying condition and sepsis.
6. DVT: The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to her immobility and sepsis.
7. Stress ulcer: The patient is at risk of developing stress ulcer due to her underlying condition and sepsis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin and pip-tazo until sensitivities return.
2. Trending CBC/diff, lactate, and LFTs.
3. Following up blood and urine cultures.
4. Continuing IVF to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg.
5. Weaning norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg.
6. Checking ScvO2.
7. Avoiding nephrotoxins.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of
   met acidosis she fatigued. Has been having recently worsening dyspnea
   on exertion, stable orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation
   in the ED. Heart failure is less likely as echo and CXR do not show any
   evidence of this. ABG shows good oxygenation and patient has been
   switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.  Some hemodynamic instability
   during SBT, with afib on AC for now.
   - Attempt to change back to PSV for now and wean as tolerated; consider
   sbt once patient can tolerate no sedation
   - wean pressors as tolerated
   - goal to extubate patient today
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Appears to be first episode as no history of
   this in past. Likely exacerbated by SBT and being on levophed in the
   setting of infection. Hemodynamically stable for now with rates in the
   110
   - EKG
   -  If fast rate persists or if worsening hemodynamics, consider
   changing levophed to phenylephrine as to reduce beta agonist activity
   and worsen afib with RVR.
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP yesterday showed significant pus and s/p stent
   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with pip-tazo until sensitivies return; d/c
   vanc as GI infection not likely MRSA.
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely. Since fluids do not seem
   to correct very fast, likely a component of ATN as well.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function with PM chem. 10.

   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. DIC and repeat labs
   equivical; low suscipicion of HIT as timing does not correlate.
   Concerning as platelets continuing to decrease. Vancomycin/ may be a
   possibility as known to cause thrombocytopenia.
   - D/C vanc and heparin today

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement yesterday.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: Intubated, on PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%, and showing good oxygenation.
* Cardiac: Atrial fibrillation (AFib) with a rate of 100-115 beats per minute (bpm), which is likely exacerbated by the septic shock and infection.
* Hemodynamic: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) 62-103 mmHg, heart rate (HR) 60-80 bpm, and respiratory rate (RR) 19 breaths per minute.
* Renal: Acute kidney injury (ARF) likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL.
* Coagulation: Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 48,000 cells per microliter (μL), which is likely secondary to sepsis and infection.
* Infection: Sepsis from cholangitis, with a white blood cell count (WBC) of 17,000 cells per μL, and a decreasing trend in WBC count.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 17,000 cells per μL, platelet count 48,000 cells per μL, and hemoglobin (Hb) 10.7 g/dL.
* Blood chemistry: Sodium (Na) 137 mmol/L, potassium (K) 4.5 mmol/L, chloride (Cl) 102 mmol/L, and lactate 1.4 mmol/L.
* Liver function tests (LFTs): Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) decreasing, and total bilirubin (Tbili) 4.5 mg/dL.
* Coagulation studies: International normalized ratio (INR) 1.1, and fibrinogen 500 mg/dL.

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray (CXR): Unimpressive, with no evidence of pneumonia or other lung disease.
* Echocardiogram (ECHO): Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) >65%, with mild mitral regurgitation (MR) and trace aortic regurgitation (AR).

The patient's current plan is to:

* Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for sepsis and cholangitis.
* Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by maintaining MAP >65 mmHg.
* Transition back to PSV and monitor respiratory and hemodynamic status closely.
* Repeat CXR and ABG as needed.
* Continue IVF boluses for CVP and UOP.
* Monitor thrombocytopenia and consider platelet transfusion if platelet count <10,000 cells per μL.
* Hold heparin products and monitor for signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve her condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cell carcinoma, and dementia who presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source.

The patient underwent ERCP and stent placement yesterday, which revealed a choledochoduodenal fistula and a 2.5-3cm filling defect consistent with a stone or sludge ball causing partial obstruction in the mid-common bile duct. The patient was found to have pus extruding from the major papilla and a biliary stent was placed successfully.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: intubated on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40%, with a respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 98%.
* Hemodynamic status: CVP 8 mmHg, MAP 99 mmHg, and HR 71 beats per minute.
* Renal function: creatinine 2.1 mg/dL, with a baseline creatinine of 1.2-1.4 mg/dL.
* Blood counts: WBC 25.0 x 10^9/L, Hct 31.6%, and platelet count 93 x 10^9/L.
* Coagulation profile: PT 14.5 seconds, PTT 1.3 seconds, and INR 1.3.
* Electrolytes: Na 137 mmol/L, K 4.5 mmol/L, Cl 102 mmol/L, and bicarbonate 22 mmol/L.
* Blood cultures: pending.

The patient is currently being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including piperacillin-tazobactam, and is receiving IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output. The patient is also being weaned off norepinephrine as tolerated.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: the patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but there is a risk of further deterioration if the patient's sepsis worsens or if there is a delay in extubation.
* Sepsis: the patient is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, but there is a risk of further septic shock if the infection is not adequately treated.
* Acute kidney injury: the patient's creatinine level is currently elevated, and there is a risk of further kidney injury if the patient's sepsis worsens or if there is a delay in treating the underlying cause.
* Thrombocytopenia: the patient's platelet count is currently low, and there is a risk of further bleeding if the patient's platelet count continues to decline.
* DIC: the patient's coagulation profile is currently abnormal, and there is a risk of further bleeding or clotting if the patient's DIC worsens.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
* Continue to treat the patient's sepsis with broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV fluids.
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further kidney injury.
* Monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further bleeding.
* Consider transfusing platelets if the patient's platelet count continues to decline.
* Continue to monitor the patient's coagulation profile and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent further bleeding or clotting.
* Consider transferring the patient to a higher level of care if the patient's condition worsens or if there is a delay in extubation.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cell carcinoma, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She has undergone ERCP and stent placement.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. The patient is being weaned from sedation and is currently on minimal sedation. She had an episode of atrial fibrillation during a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and is currently being treated with acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and metoprolol.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's cardiac index is normal, and her left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is greater than 65%. The patient has trace aortic regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. Her creatinine level is currently 2.1 mg/dL, and her urine output is improving.
* Hematological: The patient has thrombocytopenia likely secondary to sepsis. Her platelet count is decreasing, and she is at risk for bleeding.
* Infection: The patient has a biliary source of infection, and her white blood cell count is trending down. She is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and is at risk for developing a hospital-acquired infection.
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 25.0, Hct 31.6, Plt 93
	+ Blood chemistry: Glucose 195, Creatinine 2.1, Urea 14.9
	+ Liver function tests (LFTs): ALT 104, AST 59, Alk Phos 70, T Bili 4.5
	+ Electrolytes: Na 137, K 3.5, Cl 105, HCO3 22

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require further intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac index is normal, but she has trace aortic regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation, which may affect her cardiac output.
3. Renal failure: The patient's AKI is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion, and she may require further renal replacement therapy.
4. Bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia puts her at risk for bleeding, particularly with invasive procedures or surgical interventions.
5. Infection: The patient has a biliary source of infection, and she is at risk for developing a hospital-acquired infection.
6. Septic shock: The patient's septic shock may worsen, leading to further organ dysfunction and mortality.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that she continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, fluid resuscitation, and vasopressor support as needed. Further monitoring of her laboratory results, including CBC, blood chemistry, and LFTs, is necessary to guide her treatment.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications are potential concerns:

1. Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient developed AFib during a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT), which may be exacerbated by the use of levophed in the setting of infection. The patient's heart rate is currently stable, but if the rate persists or worsens, consideration should be given to changing levophed to phenylephrine to reduce beta agonist activity and worsen AFib with RVR.
2. Septic Shock: The patient is likely experiencing septic shock secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. The patient's white blood cell count is trending down, and lactate is now normal, suggesting that the initial sepsis may be resolving. However, the patient remains at risk for ongoing sepsis and should continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics.
3. Acute Respiratory Failure (ARF): The patient is experiencing ARF, which may be related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. The patient's creatinine is stable at 2.1, and urine electrolytes suggest pre-renal azotemia. The patient should continue to receive IV fluids to maintain a central venous pressure (CVP) of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreasing, likely secondary to sepsis. DIC and repeat labs are equivocal, and there is low suspicion of HIT as the timing does not correlate. The patient's platelet count should be re-checked at 1500, and transfusion should be considered for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure.
5. Mixed Anion Gap (Lactic Acid)/Non-anion Gap (NS and Diarrhea) Acidosis: The patient's acidosis has closed, and lactate is now normal. The patient should continue to receive IV fluids per sepsis protocol and give bicarbonate as needed for bicarbonate less than 18 or LR if needed for resuscitation to prevent further NG acidosis.
6. Renal Failure: The patient is at risk for ongoing renal failure, particularly given the presence of sepsis and intravascular volume depletion. The patient's creatinine is stable at 2.1, and urine electrolytes suggest pre-renal azotemia. The patient should continue to receive IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
7. Biliary Source of Infection: The patient's infection is likely secondary to a biliary source, given the presence of CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in the setting of known choledocholithiasis. The patient should continue to receive broad-spectrum antibiotics and consider further imaging or endoscopy to evaluate the biliary tree.

In terms of the patient's overall condition, the patient is stable but remains at risk for ongoing complications. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and the patient should continue to receive IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's platelet count should be re-checked at 1500, and transfusion should be considered for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure. The patient's creatinine should be trended regularly, and the patient should continue to receive IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female who underwent ERCP yesterday due to choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cell carcinoma, and dementia. She presented with dyspnea and vomiting, which complicated into acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: intubated and receiving CPAP/PSV with FiO2 40%
* Hemodynamics: CVP 8 mmHg, MAP 99/50 mmHg, HR 71 bpm, SpO2 98%
* Laboratory results: WBC 25.0, Hct 31.6, Plt 93, Cr 2.4, TropT 0.02, TCO2 18
* Imaging studies: Echo shows mild left atrial dilation, normal left ventricular function, and trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion
* Clinical assessment: patient is somewhat jaundiced, with soft, non-tender, and non-distended abdomen

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Respiratory failure: the patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of worsening respiratory failure if the patient's underlying condition worsens.
* Septic shock: the patient's septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. The patient's lactate is normal, and the initial sepsis is likely secondary to a biliary source.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): the patient's creatinine is stable at 2.1, and the urine electrolytes suggest pre-renal azotemia.
* Thrombocytopenia: the patient's platelet count is decreasing, and there is a low suspicion of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient's DIC labs are equivocal, and there are no signs of active bleeding.
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: the patient's acidosis has closed, and lactate has normalized.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing broad-spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam until sensitivities return
* Trending CBC, diff, lactate, and LFTs
* Following up blood and urine cultures
* Continuing IV fluids to maintain CVP 10-12 mmHg and good urine output
* Weaning norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
* Checking ScvO2
* Avoiding nephrotoxins and trending renal function
* Transfusing platelets if the count continues to decrease
* Repeat DIC labs
* No signs of active bleeding
* Transfusing for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure

   ERCP: The major papilla was intra-diverticular. Pus was seen extruding
   from the major papilla. An opening draining bile and pus consistent
   with a choledochoduodenal fistula was seen at the superior portion of
   the major papilla. Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and
   deep with a sphincterotome using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium
   was injected resulting in complete opacification.  A single 2.5-3cm
   filling defect consistent witha stone or sludge ball that was causing
   partial obstruction was seen at the mid CBD.  A 10FR by 5cm double
   pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully using a Oasis 10FR stent
   introducer kit.
   Echo: The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall
   thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal
   (LVEF >65%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2).
   Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
   aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is
   not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is high normal.
   There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2165-12-23**], the left
   ventricle is less dynamic, the velocity across the aortic valve is
   lower (now normal), and the severity of tricuspid regurgitation and
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure are lower.
   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but suspect in setting of
   met acidosis she fatigued. Has been having recently worsening dyspnea
   on exertion, stable orthopnea. Became acutely SOB requiring intubation
   in the ED. Heart failure is less likely as echo and CXR do not show any
   evidence of this. ABG shows good oxygenation and patient has been
   switched to PSV 10/5 with FiO2 40%.  Some hemodynamic instability
   during SBT, with afib on AC for now.
   - Attempt to change back to PSV for now and wean as tolerated; consider
   sbt once patient can tolerate no sedation
   - wean pressors as tolerated
   - goal to extubate patient today
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Appears to be first episode as no history of
   this in past. Likely exacerbated by SBT and being on levophed in the
   setting of infection. Hemodynamically stable for now with rates in the
   110
   - EKG
   -  If fast rate persists or if worsening hemodynamics, consider
   changing levophed to phenylephrine as to reduce beta agonist activity
   and worsen afib with RVR.
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP yesterday showed significant pus and s/p stent
   placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down. Lactate now
   normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source given CBD
   dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Cont broad spectrum abx with pip-tazo until sensitivies return; d/c
   vanc as GI infection not likely MRSA.
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs
   - Follow up blood cx , urine cx;  GPR may be contamination, but will
   continue to cover broadly for now until further speciation.
   - Cont IVF to keep CVP 10-12 mmHg and good UOP
   - Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by MAP >= 65 mmHg
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea. Currently stable at 2.1;  Baseline
   creatinine 1.2-1.4. - urine lytes: Fena: 0.2...pre-renal; in case she
   had lasix, FeUrea: 14.9%...pre-renal likely. Since fluids do not seem
   to correct very fast, likely a component of ATN as well.
   - IVFs for CVP 10-12
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend renal function with PM chem. 10.
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. DIC and repeat labs
   equivical; low suscipicion of HIT as timing does not correlate.
   Concerning as platelets continuing to decrease. Vancomycin/ may be a
   possibility as known to cause thrombocytopenia.
   - D/C vanc and heparin today
   - unlikely DIC at this point
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Re-check cbc at 1500
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Cont IVF per sepsis protocol; will give bicarb as needed for bicarb
   less than 18 or LR if needs resuscitation to prevent further  NG
   acidosis.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. She underwent ERCP and stent placement, and was initially treated with levophed and vancomycin. She developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate, which was treated with amiodarone. Her current medications include midazolam, phenylephrine, and heparin. Her laboratory results show thrombocytopenia, anion gap acidosis, and acute kidney injury. Her physical examination reveals a patient who is intubated and awake, with clear lung fields and a regular heart rate and rhythm.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued sepsis and septic shock: The patient's sepsis and septic shock may persist or worsen if not adequately treated.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to hemodynamic instability and decreased cardiac output if not properly managed.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly if platelet counts continue to decrease.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not adequately treated.
5. Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: The patient's acidosis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further organ dysfunction.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may persist or worsen if not adequately treated, leading to further respiratory distress.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiovascular instability may lead to decreased cardiac output and decreased blood pressure if not properly managed.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may increase the risk of bleeding and worsen her overall condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover for cholangitis and infected stone/sludge.
2. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse if necessary.
3. Continue IV fluids to maintain a CVP of 10-12 mmHg and good urine output.
4. Wean norepinephrine as tolerated by maintaining a MAP of >= 65 mmHg.
5. Trend renal function and adjust IV fluids and medications as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust medications as necessary to maintain hemodynamic stability.
8. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and adjust IV fluids and medications as necessary to maintain acid-base balance.
9. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiothoracic intensive care unit (ICU) if her cardiovascular instability persists or worsens.
10. Consider consulting a gastroenterologist to further evaluate and manage the patient's biliary disease.

   Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
   aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is
   not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is high normal.
   There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. She has developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which was initially treated with levophed and later with neosynephrine. Her blood pressure dropped with IV diltiazem, so amiodarone was started. She is also experiencing thrombocytopenia, which is likely secondary to sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may continue to worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may progress if not treated promptly and effectively, leading to organ dysfunction, shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may continue to cause hemodynamic instability, leading to decreased cardiac output, increased risk of stroke, and potential cardiac arrest.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, especially if she undergoes invasive procedures or requires surgical intervention.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and potential need for dialysis.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may continue to worsen if not managed properly, leading to further organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Vascular complications: The patient's vascular complications, such as DVT and pulmonary embolism, may increase the risk of thrombosis and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids, and monitor for signs of organ dysfunction and shock.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation and adjust treatment as needed to maintain hemodynamic stability and prevent stroke.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and adjust treatment as needed to prevent bleeding complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluids and electrolyte replacement, and monitor for signs of chronic kidney disease.
6. Continue to manage the patient's metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate therapy and monitor for signs of further organ dysfunction.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's vascular status and adjust treatment as needed to prevent thrombosis and potentially life-threatening complications.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient will be NPO pending hopeful extubation this morning, and can restart diet post-extubation.
2. Glycemic control: The patient's blood glucose levels will be monitored and managed as needed to prevent hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia.
3. Lines: The patient will have a multi-lumen, 20-gauge, and arterial line in place for monitoring and treatment.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient will receive DVT prophylaxis with pneumoboots, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and VAP bundle.

Communication:

The patient's husband and daughter will be informed of her condition and treatment plan, and will be involved in decision-making as needed. The patient has been made DNR.

   the major papilla. Cannulation of the biliary duct was successful and
   deep with a sphincterotome using a free-hand technique. Contrast medium
   was injected resulting in complete opacification.  A single 2.5-3cm
   filling defect consistent witha stone or sludge ball that was causing
   partial obstruction was seen at the mid CBD.  A 10FR by 5cm double
   pigtail biliary stent was placed successfully using a Oasis 10FR stent
   introducer kit.
   Echo: The left atrium is mildly dilated. Left ventricular wall
   thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal
   (LVEF >65%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2).
   Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The
   aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is
   not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve
   leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is high normal.
   There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2165-12-23**], the left
   ventricle is less dynamic, the velocity across the aortic valve is
   lower (now normal), and the severity of tricuspid regurgitation and
   pulmonary artery systolic pressure are lower.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED. Has
   been doing well on the ventilator, had hoped to extubate her yesterday,
   however she went into A.fib with RVR during her [**Last Name (LF) 1324**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] she was
   intially changed back to A/C, then transitioned back to PSV.
   - [**First Name3 (LF) 1324**] early this morning, discontinue sedation for hopeful extubation
   this morning
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during [**First Name3 (LF) 1324**] on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - With increasing leukocytosis concern for a new infection, will
   reculture blood, urine and sputum, also send a C.diff when patient has

s increase, will reimage RUQ due to concern

   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also likely some component of ATN

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who was admitted to the ICU with dyspnea, vomiting, and acute respiratory failure. She underwent ERCP and stent placement for a choledochoduodenal fistula. She developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate, which was treated with amiodarone. Her septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge. She has also developed acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and mixed anion gap acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate may lead to further cardiac complications, such as decreased cardiac output, increased risk of stroke, and increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Septic Shock: The patient's septic shock may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further organ dysfunction, including cardiac, renal, and respiratory failure.
3. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, anemia, and increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of bleeding and hemorrhagic complications.
5. Mixed Anion Gap Acidosis: The patient's mixed anion gap acidosis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, cardiac arrhythmias, and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
6. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as abscess formation, septicemia, and increased risk of mortality.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's cardiac status may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as cardiac failure, arrhythmias, and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with amiodarone and monitor for signs of cardiac complications.
2. Continue to manage the patient's septic shock with appropriate fluid resuscitation, vasopressors, and antibiotics, and monitor for signs of organ dysfunction.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with fluid management, electrolyte replacement, and monitoring for signs of worsening kidney function.
4. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and monitoring for signs of bleeding.
5. Continue to manage the patient's mixed anion gap acidosis with bicarbonate replacement and monitoring for signs of worsening acidosis.
6. Continue to manage the patient's cholangitis with antibiotics and monitoring for signs of abscess formation or septicemia.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely for signs of cardiac complications, such as cardiac failure, arrhythmias, or increased risk of mortality.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.2°F)
* Heart rate: 133 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 102/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 31 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* SpO2: 97%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation (AF)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 25.0 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 10.5 g/dL
* Platelet count (PLT): 93 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.6 mg/dL
* Lactate: 18 mmol/L
* Glucose: 195 mg/dL
* Calcium (Ca): 7.7 mmol/L
* Magnesium (Mg): 2.4 mmol/L
* Phosphorus (Phos): 1.7 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: Volume overloaded
* Echocardiogram: Mild left atrial dilatation, normal left ventricular function, and mild tricuspid regurgitation

The patient's medical history includes:

* Choledocholithiasis
* Hypertension
* Renal cell carcinoma
* Dementia

The patient's current medications include:

* Vancomycin
* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Midazolam (Versed)
* Phenylephrine
* Diltiazem
* Amiodarone
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis)

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning off the ventilator and extubation tomorrow pending ability to diurese
* Monitoring for improvement and hopeful discontinuation of amiodarone once patient is extubated and off sedation
* Reculturing blood, urine, and sputum, and sending a C. difficile test when patient has a bowel movement
* Trending CBC/diff, LFTs, and creatinine levels
* Weaning neo as tolerated by MAP >= 60 mmHg
* Continuing to hold vanc/heparin and transfusing platelets if necessary

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely secondary to a biliary source, and she may require continued antibiotics and supportive care.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and she may require continued dialysis or other forms of renal replacement therapy.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and she may require continued platelet transfusions.
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis: The patient's acidosis has resolved, but she may require continued monitoring and treatment.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's blood pressure is unstable, and she may require continued vasopressor support.
* Infection: The patient's infection is likely secondary to a biliary source, and she may require continued antibiotics and supportive care.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding is a potential complication, and she may require continued monitoring and treatment.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and mild tricuspid regurgitation are potential cardiovascular complications, and she may require continued monitoring and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who presented with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement, and her course has been complicated by atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, thrombocytopenia, and mixed anion gap acidosis. She remains intubated and on pressors, and her current vital signs are T 99.2, BP 102/56, HR 72-141, RR 20's, and Sat 97% on PS 10/5 40%.

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued septic shock: The patient's septic shock is likely secondary to cholangitis and infected stone/sludge, and she remains on pressors to maintain her blood pressure.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is being treated with amiodarone, and her heart rate remains elevated.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely secondary to sepsis and may be exacerbated by vancomycin.
4. Mixed anion gap acidosis: The patient's acidosis is resolving, but she may still require further treatment to address her electrolyte imbalance.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely related to her septic shock and may require continued ventilatory support.
6. ARF: The patient's acute renal failure is likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion.
7. Thrombotic complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and mixed anion gap acidosis may increase her risk of thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
8. Infection: The patient's rising white blood cell count and mixed anion gap acidosis suggest that she may still have an active infection, which could be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and vomiting may lead to further dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, which could exacerbate her septic shock and other complications.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust her pressors and ventilatory support as needed to maintain her blood pressure and oxygenation.
3. Continue to treat her atrial fibrillation with amiodarone.
4. Monitor her thrombocytopenia and consider transfusing platelets if her platelet count remains low.
5. Continue to treat her mixed anion gap acidosis with bicarbonate and other electrolytes as needed.
6. Consider adding broad-spectrum antibiotics if the patient's infection is not responding to treatment.
7. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms and consider treating her diarrhea and vomiting with anti-diarrheal medications and electrolyte supplements.
8. Consider repeating blood cultures and imaging studies to rule out any other potential sources of infection.
9. Continue to educate the patient's family about her condition and treatment plan, and involve them in her care as needed.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED.
   Unable to wean effectively; likely secondary to fluid resuscitation; as
   fluid overload is seen on CXR.
   - Monitor UOP as patient is auto-diuresing well. Check i/o
s this
   evening with TBB 1-1.5 liters
   - Wean down vent settings as much as possible, will likely be more
   effective once
   - CXR today to make sure no other acute process is occuring
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during SBT on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Continue amio gtt as HR has improved, but she is still tachycardic in
   the low 100
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - Leukocytosis is resolveing, T max was yesterday at 1600; appears to
   be improving.
   - Cont zosyn pending any further culture data; Day [**5-19**] of zosyn. Day
   1: [**11-22**].
   - f/u speciation and sensitivities from prior blood cx
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs,
   - Follow up blood cx speciation , urine cx with no growth
   - no need for pressors now. Monitor maps > 65.
   .
   # ARF: Improved, near baseline. Likely related to sepsis and
   intravascular volume depletion secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also
   likely some component of ATN as her renal function has not improved as
   quickly with fluids as would be expected in a purely pre-renal picture.
   Cr improving to 1.5 today, baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - Monitor UOP
   - Trend creatinine
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Stable. Likely secondary to sepsis. Low suscipicion
   of HIT as timing does not correlate since patient has not had a prior
   heparin exposure.  Vancomycin may also be contributing to her
   thrombocytopenia
   - Continue to hold vanc/heparin
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   - If platelets remain stable or increase tomorrow would restart heparin
   as HIT is very unlikely
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Bicarb 24 today, extubation will be facilitated by resolution of
   acidosis.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: OG tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female who presented with dyspnea and vomiting, complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 141 bpm
* Blood pressure: 109/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Amylase: 16 IU/L
* Lipase: 102 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient has a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cell carcinoma, and dementia.

The patient's medical conditions and complications include:

* Acute respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Atrial fibrillation
* Thrombocytopenia
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis
* Acute kidney injury (ARF)
* Cholangitis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotics (Zosyn)
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Vancomycin (held due to thrombocytopenia)
* Fluid resuscitation
* Nutrition via OG tube feeds
* Glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's disposition is currently in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued septic shock and organ dysfunction
* Atrial fibrillation and related complications
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Acute kidney injury and related complications
* Cholangitis and related complications
* Respiratory failure and related complications
* Infection and sepsis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding and related complications

   Assessment and Plan
   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to biliary source. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
   # Dyspnea/respiratory failure: Resp failure does not appear [**3-13**] primary
   lung process, as CXR is rather unimpressive, but in the setting of her
   metabolic acidosis she was hyperventilating to compensate and
   fatigued. Becoming acutely SOB and requiring intubation in the ED. Has
   been doing well on the ventilator, had hoped to extubate her yesterday,
   however she went into A.fib with RVR during her [**Last Name (LF) 1324**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] she was
   intially changed back to A/C, then transitioned back to PSV.
   - RSBI early this morning
patient very tachypnei,
   -Chest x-ray appeared volume overloaded, which is likely contributing
   to the difficulty weaning her off the ventilator, when patient is able
   to be weaned off pressors will need diuresis.  Hopefully patient will
   start to mobilize her extra fluid, however once off pressors if she is
   unable to, will give lasix as needed to help decrease the fluid in her
   lungs
   - Hopeful extubation today pending ability to diurese
   # Atrial Fibrillation: First occurred during [**First Name3 (LF) 1324**] on [**11-23**], initially
   rates were in the 110
s, then increased to the 130
s, pressor changed
   from levophed to neo without any effect, her BP dropped with IV dilt,
   so started amiodarone morning of [**11-24**] due to continued pressor
   requirement
   - Monitor for improvement and hopeful d/c of amio once patient is
   extubated and off sedation
   # Septic shock:  Likely secondary to cholangitis and infected
   stone/sludge. ERCP showed significant pusand very large stone, she is
   s/p stent placement. Patient afebrile and white count trending down.
   Lactate now normal. Initial sepsis likely secondary to biliary source
   given CBD dilation with sludge and obstructive LFTs in setting on known
   choledocholithiasis. No other source of infection found.
   - With increasing leukocytosis concern for a new infection, will
   reculture blood, urine and sputum, also send a C.diff when patient has
   a bowel movement, if LFT
s increase, will reimage RUQ due to concern
   for possible blockage of stent
   - Cont zosyn pending any further culture data; f/u speciation and
   sensitivities from prior blood cx
   - Trend CBC/diff, LFTs, especially in the setting on increasing
   leukocytosis, will add on Diff to AM labs
   - Follow up blood cx speciation , urine cx with no growth
   - Wean neo as tolerated by MAP >= 60 mmHg
   # ARF: Likely related to sepsis and intravascular volume depletion
   secondary to vomiting and diarrhea, also likely some component of ATN
   as her renal function has not improved as quickly with fluids as would
   be expected in a purely pre-renal picture. Cr improving to 1.5 today,
   baseline creatinine 1.2-1.4.
   - Titrate MAP to greater than 60, unless urine output decreases then
   will titrate to increased MAP
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia Likely secondary to sepsis. Low suscipicion of HIT as
   timing does not correlate since patient has not had a prior heparin
   exposure.  Vancomycin may also be contributing to her
   thrombocytopenia.  Platelets slightly increased today.
   - Continue to hold vanc/heparin
   - No signs of active bleeding
   - Transfuse for less than 10,000 or 30,000 for procedure
   - If platelets remain stable or increase tomorrow would restart heparin
   as HIT is very unlikely
   # Mixed Anion gap (lactic acid)/Non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea)
   acidosis:  Gap has closed. Lactate normalized.
    - Bicarb 24 today, extubation will be facilitated by resolution of
   acidosis.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cancer, and dementia who was admitted with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory failure and septic shock likely secondary to a biliary source. She underwent ERCP and stent placement. The patient has been intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. She has been experiencing atrial fibrillation, which is being treated with amiodarone. The patient's white blood cell count is increasing, and she has been prescribed antibiotics, including Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn).

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 141 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 109/60 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 25 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 17.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 48 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 24 mmol/L
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* Alanine aminotransferase: 70 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase: 36 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 102 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 2.5 mg/dL
* Amylase: 16 IU/L
* Lipase: 102 IU/L

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Atrial fibrillation
* Thrombocytopenia
* Acute kidney injury
* Mixed anion gap acidosis

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia
* Ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Sepsis
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Bleeding complications
* Renal failure
* Hepatic failure
* Pancreatitis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotic therapy with Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Anti-coagulation therapy with heparin
* Platelet transfusion
* Diuresis therapy
* Monitoring for signs of infection and sepsis
* Monitoring for signs of bleeding and thrombocytopenia
* Monitoring for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Monitoring for signs of renal failure and acute kidney injury
* Monitoring for signs of hepatic failure and pancreatitis

The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. She is also receiving midazolam and amiodarone infusions.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL (normal range: 1.8-3.0 mg/dL)
* PO4: 2.2 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL)

The patient's medical history includes choledocholithiasis, hypertension, renal cell carcinoma, and dementia.

The patient's current medications include:

* Midazolam (Versed) - 2 mg/hour
* Amiodarone - 0.5 mg/min
* Fentanyl - 5:00 PM

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Thrombocytopenia
* Mixed anion gap (lactic acid)/non-anion gap (NS and diarrhea) acidosis
* Biliary sepsis
* Cholangitis
* Pancreatitis

The patient's plan includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Weaning of mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotic therapy with Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Fluid resuscitation
* Nutritional support with OG tube feeds
* Glycemic control
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Follow-up with CBC, LFTs, and blood cultures
* Potential need for a PICC line and a full 10-day course of Zosyn.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, dementia, and renal cancer, who presents with septic shock and cholangitis, following ERCP with stent placement. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 128 bpm (114-141 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 111/67 mmHg (76-127/70 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute (14-30 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 17.8-20.2 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 48-59 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.5-2.1 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Atrial fibrillation
* Thrombocytopenia

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning of pressure support as tolerated
* Checking of CXR
* Goal TBB of -1 to -1.5 L today
* Giving of prn lasix
* Restarting of SC heparin when platelet count >50,000
* Continuing of amiodarone drip

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further respiratory failure
* Septic shock progression
* Development of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia
* Worsening of atrial fibrillation
* Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism due to immobility
* Development of VAP due to prolonged intubation
* Increased risk of stress ulceration due to critical illness
* Development of kidney injury due to sepsis and hypotension
* Development of liver dysfunction due to sepsis and hypotension

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the patient is currently in the ICU with a critical illness.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of choledocholithiasis, dementia, and renal cancer who presents with septic shock and cholangitis, requiring ERCP with stenting, and respiratory failure necessitating ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.2°C (97.2°F)
* Heart rate: 128 bpm
* Blood pressure: 111/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 99%
* Oxygen delivery device: Endotracheal tube
* Ventilator mode: CPAP/PSV
* Vt (set): 500 mL
* Vt (spontaneous): 380 mL
* PS: 12 cmH2O
* PEEP: 5 cmH2O
* FiO2: 40%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.8
* Hematocrit: 30.8%
* Platelet count: 48 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02
* Lactic acid: 1.7 mmol/L
* LDH: 203 IU/L
* Ca++: 7.7 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.2 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.2 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: likely secondary to volume overload, with a goal to reduce tidal volume by 1-1.5 L today and provide prn lasix.
* Septic shock: off pressors, autodiuresing, on Zosyn, with improving leukocytosis and LFTs.
* Atrial fibrillation: on amiodarone drip, with plans to continue for now.
* Thrombocytopenia: stable, with no signs of active bleeding, and plans to restart SC heparin when appropriate.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Further deterioration of respiratory failure, potentially requiring more aggressive ventilation or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Progression of septic shock, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
* Development of arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to atrial fibrillation.
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia, potentially requiring transfusions or platelet support.
* Potential for kidney injury or failure due to septic shock and/or hypotension.
* Increased risk of nosocomial infections, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSIs).
* Potential for cardiac tamponade or other cardiac complications due to atrial fibrillation and/or septic shock.
* Increased risk of delirium and cognitive decline due to septic shock, hypotension, and/or respiratory failure.
* Potential for gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to septic shock and/or hypotension.

Based on the patient's current condition and laboratory results, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and hematological status, as well as provide aggressive treatment for septic shock and atrial fibrillation.

   85yo F with a h/o choledocholithiasis, HTN, renal CA, and dementia who
   presents with dyspnea and vomiting complicated by acute respiratory
   failure and septic shock likely secondary to cholangitis. She is s/p
   ERCP and stent.
   .
